ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Nonclassical Logics: paraconsistent logics, relevant logics, connexive logics, etc.
I learned about a range of nonclassical logics (relevance, para-consistent, quantum, intuitionistic) and actually got a good understanding of their mathematical foundations from the PSETs.
Learned about different extensions and deviations of nonclassical logics such as: logic of paradox, intuitionistic logics, relevance logics, etc.
Exposure to several logics and the reasons for why we create and use them. It's a really great class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course materials are very interesting. I feel that the course assumes a fair degree of background in logic (math logic).

Solid handouts are talked through in the lecture and essential for the PSETs, so the PSETs feel extremely relevant and instructive. The lectures themselves are engaging and you learn a lot, not just about the particular logic you're looking at that day but how it fits into the broader picture of nonclassical logics.

The instructor is very engaging and very dedicated to his students. Problem sets were interesting, lectures were great.

The problem sets were a bit challenging, not undoable, but unevenly distributed  first couple problem sets needed substantially more work than the others.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, particularly math and philosophy majors!
If you are interested in nonclassical logics, absolutely. MB is a great instructor and the course content is very interesting. I overall learned a lot.
